title: Examples that would earn this point might include the following: •	As central authority in the Benin Kingdom, the Oba also controlled trade, including for brass/bronze that the plaque is made from. •	The wealth of the Oba is emphasized through coral and by the horse, which were both acquired through trade and only owned by individuals of elite status.  •	The medium, brass, was a trade item acquired principally through trade with Portugal. It was reserved for use in royal art of Benin to reflect wealth and status of the ruler, which emphasizes the importance of trade. •	Objects from bronze/brass were principally reserved for art of royal patronage, and items would be created by skilled artisans and artists in workshops associated with the royal court.  •	The rosettes decorating the background of the plaque might also be influenced by Portuguese trade items and also emphasize connection between trade and royal status.  •	Benin society was highly stratified; the Oba serves as king and central political, military, and spiritual leader who ruled for life. •	The maintenance of social order and stability was considered to be important in Benin society for ensuring the wellbeing of society. •	The Oba’s legitimacy was connected to his ancestral descendance from a lineage of divine rulers. •	The  plaque was originally mounted to decorate Oba’s palace together with similar reliefs featuring kings or other important individuals, events, or scenes of courtly life connected to the Benin Kingdom and intended to convey the legitimacy of the King.  •	The placement of the plaque at the Benin royal palace complex among other plaques represented the Oba’s divine lineage and descent from Oranmiyan, the founder of the royal lineage of Benin. •	The plaque was part of a palace display that served as a device through which oral histories were recounted and preserved. •	The Oba had a spiritual, as well as political, leadership role in Benin society. •	The spiritual power of the Oba / importance of knowledge and intellect is emphasized through his large head, which was considered to be the seat of intellectual and spiritual power and will. •	Like other depictions of royal/elite individuals, the Benin wall plaque follows strict conventions intended to emphasize the status and authority of the ruler and reinforce the order of society. •	The hierarchy of perspective and frontal depiction provide clarity and reinforce the Oba’s divine leadership through conventions used for centuries. •	The inclusion of attendants and servants in the plaque, and the emphasis of their servant role (for example by shading the ruler, supporting his hands, carrying his sword, drumming his arrival) emphasize the status of the Oba as well as the importance of the support of his servants and others for his ability to rule.
